answerText: "The Bishop Orders His Tomb at St. Praxed's Church"[10] In this dramatic monologue by the author of "The Bishop Orders his Tomb," a beautiful woman is strangled with her own hair, and the murderer muses over the lovely corpse.
heading: Penn Bowl |2012 | 7 | 9 | Literature | British | College
subject: Literature
question: Question: John Ruskin said it summarized the Renaissance with its "hypocrisy, ignorance, and [love of luxury]." For ten points each: [10] Name this poem in which a man requests "peach-blossom marble" and whines to his so-called "nephews" about being cheated by old Gandolf.
